The fact that the definition of "arms" has changed since the Constitution was written justifies reinterpreting the phrase "right to bear arms".  The question really isn't whether the constitution should be interpretive, but rather how much so and in what way. If the way we interpret it needs to change, that needs to be dealt with via constitutional process rather than ignoring what it says. Re. the 2nd Amendment issue, IMO that amendment in the Bill of Rights makes people free to own and bear arms, period--the wording is clear. If that needs to change because of the effectiveness of modern technology, or because we don't need the concept of a "militia", then due process should be followed and the amendment needs to be replaced or somehow reworded rather than just essentially ignored. IOW, I feel that going so far as to ignore an amendment takes interpretation too far. 
 
 When it was found that prohibition was a bad idea, we didn't leave the 18th amendment there and simply interpret it differently; we declared it null through due process. This was the correct way of handling the matter. If the 2nd Amendment (or ANY amendment) is outdated, it should be dealt with (either replacing it or changing it) through constitutional due process rather than interpretively ignoring it. Now, that's no easy task, and probably wouldn't go over. But it's the process.

 Otehr parts of the constitution, though, are not as flexible. For example, the first ammendment provides for the freedom of speach and the freedom of press (among other things). While those who wrote the constitution and those whoe ratified it certainly had a different idea of what constitutes press, and probably even "speech" than we have today, But that does not meant that the underlying right laid forth in the ammendment has changed. Despite the fact that if any of those who had penned that ammendment saw a television they would likely have fallen down in fear, MSNBC is still protected by the freedom of press. Despite the fact that those who ratified the constituion had no idea what a PA system was, or what talk radio was, the concept of freedom of speech has not changed.
 
 Likewise with the second ammendment. While the founding fathers and the people at the time were certainly not dealing with AR-15s or M-60 machine guns, it was made abundantly clear that the "arms" referred to in the second ammednemnt were those of the type "commonly in miliary use". The people are, according to our constitution, to be as well armed as the government, at least on the defensive side of things. Even in this, small changes have been made that are, IMO appropriate. For years, right up into the 20th century, there were large portions of the country that actually required every able bodied man to own a gun.
